item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

No where do you have it even call the status. All you have it do is call the int “bravery”, which would return 5, but you don’t have

System.out.println(status);

EDIT:

Status: 98 Stamina: 35 Energy: 80 Health is stable. Stamina increasing to stable amount...checking...45 Status: 98 Stamina: 45 Energy: 80 Energy needs enhancement... Status: 98 Stamina: 45 Energy: 125 Batman has been temporarily replenished. Energy: 25 Health: 78 Bravery: 5 Status: Rejuvenating Increasing Stats Bravery increasing... Energy: 50 Health: 100 Bravery: 6 Status: You are a wimp!

seems to work fine to me…

item.title: String status not working
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

You’re not outputting the [tt]status [java.lang.String][/tt] field anywhere. It’s not being passed onto anything, not being printed out; it’s just sitting there.

Was this a serious question? Or did you take this off somewhere and need help to finish it - because if you programmed this yourself you would never have asked this question.

Read full topic

item.title: String status not working
item.dc:creator: @dogzound5 dogzound5@gmail.com
item.description:
@dogzound5 wrote:

Ok I have set up if() statements in my code with a String status = “” in it to be played if a certain variable is less than a number, but the quote is not being displayed.

Here is my main class

[code]class SuperHero {
public static void main(String[] args) {
Hero batman = new Hero();
batman.status = “fighting”;
batman.health = 98;
batman.stamina = 35;
batman.energy = 80;

	batman.showAttributes();
	System.out.println("Health is stable.");
	System.out.println("Stamina increasing to stable amount...checking...45");
	batman.stamina = 45;
	batman.showAttributes();
	System.out.println("Energy needs enhancement...");
	batman.energy = 125;
	batman.showAttributes();
	System.out.println("Batman has been temporarily replenished.");

	Virgil vgl = new Virgil();
	vgl.status = "Rejuvenating";
	vgl.health = 78;
	vgl.bravery = 5;
	vgl.energy = 25;

	vgl.showAttributes();
	vgl.checkBravery();
	System.out.println("Increasing Stats");
	vgl.bravery++;
	vgl.checkBravery();
	vgl.health = 100;
	vgl.energy = 50;
	vgl.checkBravery();
	System.out.println("Bravery increasing...");
	vgl.showAttributes();
	
	}
}


	[/code]

Here are my two subclasses

[code]class Hero extends SuperHero{

String status;
int health;
int stamina;
int energy; 

void checkHealth() {
	if (health < 50 || stamina < 10 || energy < 35) {
		status = "Hero, you are too weak to fight";
		}
	}
void showAttributes() {
	System.out.println("Status: " + health);
	System.out.println("Stamina: "  + stamina);
	System.out.println("Energy: " + energy);
	}
}[/code]

[code]class Virgil extends SuperHero{

String status;
int energy;
int health;
int bravery;

void checkBravery() {
	if (bravery <= 10) {
		status = "You are a wimp!";
		}
	}
void showAttributes() {
	System.out.println("Energy: " + energy);
	System.out.println("Health: " + health);
	System.out.println("Bravery: " + bravery);
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
